Players are dealt a face-down hand of six tiles corresponding to the six people in the office. On a player's turn they can either (1) turn over one of their tiles -- revealing which of the four jobs that person has been tasked with; or (2) place a tile or stack of tiles on top of another tile or stack of tiles that share a common characteristic (either person or job). Play continues until the last face-down tile is turned over. Whoever has the fewest tiles in front of them (i.e., the least overtime work to do) wins!

Re-implements: Who is going to do the dishes?
37477.name: Osaki ni Shitsurei Shima-su!!
boardgamepodcastepisode: HLG 7: Op de foto

37478.name: Trick & Treat!
37478.description:
It's time for some Halloween mischief. The parents pick the tricks and everyone tries to accumulate the treats. Who will be able to get the most candy?

The deck contains 90 number cards in 6 suits and 16 trick cards. The number cards are dealt out to the players. Players take turns choosing the "tricks" -- rules for different types of card tricks. Rules include the One-Shot (everyone plays a card simultaneously and the highest card gets points), the Center (everyone plays a card simultaneously and everything except the high and low cards gets points), and the Single Color (players play cards once around following suit if possible with the highest card in the led suit getting points). Play continues until all cards have been played. Whoever accumulates the most points wins!

boardgamehonor: 2004 Japan Boardgame Prize Best Japanese Game Nominee
37479.description:
The Pharaoh is getting old and he does not have a successor. One day he gathers his closest advisers and issues a challenge: "Build me a pyramid. Whoever contributes the most shall be the next Pharaoh!". Who will rise the challenge and become the new ruler of the land?

Players roll dice and draw event cards to maneuver their pyramid-building blocks around the board and into the pyramid at the center. Points are scored for each block added to the pyramid. Bonus points are given for blocks that end up on the outside of the pyramid. Players need to manage their supply of building blocks carefully since the board is cleared after each level of the pyramid is completed and buying back the blocks costs points. After the pyramid is completed whoever has the most points wins.
37479.name: Pyramid Pyramid

37480.name: SToCKBRoKER
37480.description: A game about playing the stock market involving cards, game spaces, stock purchases, and fluctuating stock valuations. Built on a highly detailed and involved board.

37481.name: Disney Pixar WALL-E Treasure Race Game
37481.description:
Players are one of five characters; WALL-E, EVE, Auto, M-O, or GO-4. The goal of the game is to be the first player to reach the top of the treasure pile.

Game is downloadable from the Official WALL-E Treasure Race Game website at http://www.walle-game.com/. Players print and build the board, cards, and pieces. There is also a tie-in with the National Raisin Company which has specially packaged boxes of raisins that convert into the players tokens.

37482.description:
This is a game system aimed at providing a campaign framework for players of General Quarters III and other naval wargames for their Solomon Island games. It is the first part of ODGW's Decision at Sea series.

The game determines weather, random events, intelligence reports, etc. for each month-long campaign turn. Scenarios are generated by a decision tree approach rather than map based movement. Air, submarine and surface warfare is included. The initial Battle of Savo Island includes scenario specific rules and can also be played separate from a campaign. The game can be played with or without a referee.
37482.name: The Solomons Campaign

37483.name: Lettra
37483.description:
This is a promotional game not freely available. It was given to customers of UBS (Big Swiss Bank).
Players form words with as many letters possible from their hands. Afterwards they fill up their hands with cards from their Stock. The game itself is kind of similar to "Scrabble Cardgame" except in this game you are allowed to exchange letters in existing words. The game ends when a player has used up his stock of 30 cards.

37484.description:
The year is 1959 and world has descended into madness. A Capitalist Empire, lead from Washington D.C., is locked in mortal conflict with the Communist Bloc, controlled by an iron fisted Kremlin. For how eagerly the two sides have rattled their sabers, neither power is truly prepared for total war in the nuclear age. Tanks and missile cruisers, jet fighters and Kalashnikovs, roll off assembly lines and straight into one of a dozen charred wastelands strewn across the globe. Each side prays for a quick victory, as neither can sustain the horrors of the nuclear age for long.

DEFCON 1 is a diceless wargame meant to loosely simulate a nuclear war between the US and the Soviet Union. The game supposes that neither nation’s economy is prepared for nuclear conflict. Production represents the sole random chance element in the game. Each turn, players draw random units according to the size of their economy, and strategically deploy them across the globe, each side struggling to achieve victory by taking their opponent’s homeland before their economy suffers total collapse.
37484.name: DEFCON ONE: The Cold War Goes Hot

37485.description: Bingo variant for Ages 4 and up. A plastic dispenser deals out two plastic tiles per turn, the first player to see a match between the picture on the tile and on their cards gets to claim the tile. Get three tiles in a row to win. Zingo with marvel heroes in every tile.
37485.name: Zingo! Heroes

37486.name: Sabotage
37486.description: Sabotage is a card game coming right out of World War II. In keeping with the war effort, the theme of the game is for two, three or four players (or two teams) to establish at least three factories (Tank, Aeroplane and Shipping) by gathering the required resources while trying to avoid the damaging effects of bombs and SABOTAGE!

37487.name: Balancing Board Game
37487.description: A simple dexterity game - the play area consists of a disc suspended from a pole. Players take turns to roll the colour dice and choose which type of weight to add to the disc. Larger weights score more points. The game continues until the disc tips over.

37488.name: Balloon Race
37488.description:
Can you get all your balloons safely into the stratosphere? But watch out for falling hailstones!

Each player has 4 balloons and tries to move all of them from the bottom to the top row of the Sky Grid. The first player to do so wins the game. If a balloon hits a hailstone then the balloon is burst and returns to the bottom row. Players may also burst other players balloons by squashing it between their own balloons and/or a hailstone. Balloons can jump diagonally over balloons of the same colour (counts as one move) all the way up the Sky Grid thus being an efficient way of using the action-points allocated each turn.

To begin a game, the 10 hailstones are lined up in the stratosphere (one in each square). Each player places their pawn on the corresponding 'Big Balloon' space on the Flight Path on the outside of the board. Then players place their balloons on any squares on the bottom of the Sky Grid (each player places one balloon in turn until all balloons are placed). Several balloons can occupy the same square for the first 3 rows (green area). Beyond row 3 (in the blue area) - only one balloon to a square.

On a player's turn they roll a 10-sided dice and move their pawn around the Flight Path. When the pawn lands on or passes certain squares it gives that player a number of action-points (1-4) in which to move their balloons in an upwards direction (vertical or diagonal). The action-points may be split among the player's balloons as they see fit. When a player's pawn lands on a 'Storm Clouds' square on the Flight Path the player must move any hailstone of their choice down one square. If a player's pawn lands on a 'Wind Clouds' square the player must move any one of their balloons one square sideways (if that is impossible - their lowest balloon is deemed burst, and falls back to the ground.)

Players can choose to stop their pawn on the Storm/Wind Clouds squares even if the number thrown on the dice could take the pawn past.

When a player's pawn passes or lands on a Kite/Cloud square in the corner of the Flight Path the player also throws the dice to determine which of the 10 hailstones moves down one square.

The game ends when one player has moved all their balloons to the top of the Sky Grid or when a hailstone hits the ground (in which case each balloon carries a score for the height it has reached, the highest total score then wins the game). For a quicker game, players can agree that the first balloon to reach the stratosphere ends the game - then the highest total score wins.

37489.name: Burger Wars
37489.description:
From the Game Box:

"This is a unique and imaginative game. A battle of wits, strategy and nerves. The Burger Franchise Managers of Mr. Jones take one those of Mr. Megabux for World domination of the Burger business. This game is easy to learn yet there is an infinite variety of strategies and moves."

37490.name: Lumps, the Game of Big Rolls and Smart Holds
37490.description:
The goal is to be the first player to score 100 points. On each turn, a player gets three rolls to make as many points as possible. You score points by rolling the same number on your dice. If you roll a pair of 2s, you get two points. If you roll a pair of 6s, you get six points.

What makes the game unique is that it uses four different types of dice, each with a different highest number. For example, the game has two 10 sided dice and their highest number is 10. They are the only dice that can make a pair of ten. All dice have the numbers 1-4 on them, so it is much easier to make a pair of a lower number.

Each turn players have to use strategy to determine which dice they’ve rolled are the best to keep and the best to re-roll. Do you chance it and try to make a pair of 8s, or play it safe and hold a pair of 4s? Figuring out the right move in a game with countless possibilities will keep you thinking, laughing and cheering for hours on end.

37491.name: Modern Land Battles (MLB): Target Acquired
37491.description:
Description from the publisher:

Modern Land Battles (MLB): Target Acquired uses the core game mechanisms from our award-winning Modern Naval Battles game. MLB takes you to the front lines in both historical and hypothetical conflicts ranging from the Arab-Israeli Wars to the present day.

This new game features armor, infantry and artillery vehicles from 7 different nations: USA, USSR, UK, China, Israel, Insurgent, and Arabian Multinational. This gives you the forces you need to play out battles during the Cold War, Six-Day War, Iran-Iraq War, Vietnam War, Lebanon War, Yom Kippur War, Falkland Islands War, and Gulf War.

The game system maximizes player decision making to make every turn exciting. At the start of the game, you get to select a nation's ground forces to command. Then, you get to select the specific armor, infantry, and artillery forces that you think is the best battle force. Once selected, you'll get to battle the forces selected by the other players in order to capture and secure vital objectives!

37492.name: La course des Gumballs
37492.description:
Contents : 4 pawns shaped like gumball machines full of coloured plastic balls, 1 board with coloured circles.

When you push a pawn down, all balls inside your gumball goes down except one. You must then move your gumball to the nearest circle of this colour. The white ball is a joker, and some circles allows you to move faster (bridges) or slower (sticking gum). The first to pass the arrival line wins.

37493.description: "Take a turn and make a line up: a fun game for all ages that is not as simple as it looks." Twelve cubes with each face a different colour populate a 6x6 board. Players take turns to roll a cube from one square to another with the object of completing a line of three cubes with the same colour uppermost.
37493.name: Rubik's Line Up

37494.description:
From the back cover:

"In the thirty-first century, the BattleMech reigns as king of the battlefield. But this title is not undisputed. Thundering down from deep space fly squadrons of deadly aerospace fighters, bristling with weapons rivaling the heaviest 'Mechs and loaded with deadly bombs. Their mission: to defend the space-faring DropShips and JumpShips, the lifeblood of every successful military operation.

Add the exciting dimension of aerospace combat to your BattleTech games with AeroTech 2. A companion to the BattleTech Master Rules, Revised, this book contains all the rules and background material you need to add aerospace fighters, WarShips and other spacecraft to your BattleTech and RPG games. These rules also support stand-alone air- or space-combat scenarios.

This Revised Edition of the rulebook has been extensively expanded and incorporates more than four years of player feedback to create the most comprehensive set of aerospace rules yet published for the BattleTech universe."
37494.name: BattleTech: AeroTech 2
boardgameexpansion: BattleTech Compendium: The Rules of Warfare

37495.name: Co-op Train Game
37495.description:
A cooperative print-and-play children's game where one to four players work together to try to complete as many deliveries as possible before nightfall.

The board depicts 16 stations connected by rail lines. On the delivery stations (beige), one of each of the eight destination tiles are placed randomly, face up. On each of the pick-up stations (green), two passenger/freight tiles are placed randomly, face down. Players roll a die to move (and sometimes advance the sun along its path in the sky). As trains arrive at a pick-up station, players reveal the goods/passengers. Sometimes, the player will load them onto their cars (limited number of cars on each train). Sometimes, they will leave them for other players to pick up. A player can even take a passenger part-way and leave them for another train to complete the job later.

The idea is to work together to see how many jobs will be completed before the game ends.

37496.name: Flinke Bürste
37496.description:
The title translates to Quick (tooth) Brush.

Two horseshoe shaped wood pieces carry 20 wooden teeth pieces, zero to three wood rings are laid over the teeth, the players walk around this "mouth" with their pieces, wooden tooth brushes. One die shows how far they may go, another die specifies what action to perform: brush away one ring, two rings, do nothing or advance a bacterium to the teeth.
If the bacterium reaches the teeth before the players have cleaned all of them, the players lose.

37497.name: Bilekuosi
37497.description:
Taken from the publisher´s website:
Bilekuosi / Dope Fiend is a card game whose events take place on a rough day of partying at a festival. The goal in the game is to be the first to gain 20 Mood points without losing one's consciousness, sanity or life. To achieve this, the players must hustle and get wasted with everything they can get their hands on. The game is flavored with black humour and it models drug combinations quite realistically.

Warning:
Bilekuosi / Dope Fiend has an adult theme and is therefore recommended to those Ages 15 and up

37498.name: Monopoly: The Beatles Collector's Edition
37498.description: This version of Monopoly, licensed by Apple Studios, is based upon the English band "The Beatles". The goal is to collect Beatles albums from "Please, Please Me" to "Let It Be". The pewter tokens include a walrus, a sun, a raccoon, a octopus, a strawberry, and a hammer. The currency is "All You Need Is Love" money. The houses have been renamed listening parties, and the hotels have been renamed concerts. The Income Tax space has been renamed "Taxman" and the Luxury Tax space has been renamed "Ticket To Ride". The properties are albums and points of interest with Boardwalk and Park Place renamed Apple Studios and Abbey Road Studios.

37500.name: Monopoly: My Disney Villains
37500.description: In this version of Monopoly the most notorious villains of over 50 Disney films allow you to create your own evil empire by picking 22 of 30 wicked villains to put on the board in place of Boardwalk and Park Place. The six collectible pewter tokens include the Evil Queen's crown, Jafar's hat, Captain Hook's hat, the Mad Hatter's hat, Maleficent's horns (from Sleeping Beauty), and Frollo's hat (from The Hunchback of Notre Dame).
